explanation: The report is correct. The code uses the expression (size + off) to decide whether to crop the incoming chunk, but size is size_t while off is uint64_t (different unsigned widths). The addition is performed in unsigned modular arithmetic after the usual arithmetic conversions, so a very large size value can wrap around and produce a small sum that passes the bounds check. For example, with sizeof(session->value_2) == 256, off == 200 and size == SIZE_MAX - 100, size + off wraps to 99 which is < 256, so the crop is not applied and memcpy(&session->value_2[off], data, size) will attempt to copy a huge number of bytes and overflow the buffer. Because memcpy can then access beyond the bounds of the destination object, this is a genuine violation of MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17.
